metadata.name: Fizz 2.0 #34
metadata.description:
Experimental Art.

This piece is inspired by a mathematical theorem known as 'Circle packing'. This algorithm aims to cram a bunch of circles into space as tightly as possible. This is a well-explored topic throughout the history of mathematics, but at the end of the day it's mathematics, it's BORING. So to make 'Fizz' a little bit thrilling and different, I wrote an algorithm that randomly draws 450 circles with totally different radiuses (range(width * 0.1, width * 0.001) to be exact) on a canvas, and checks each circle, if the randomly chosen location is a good fit for a new circle to avoid collisions.

Combined with some cool colors and gradients for both the background and the circles, this procedure is all it took to produce 'Fizz'.
Bereft of meaning, feel free to interpret it as you please.

metadata.name: Emotional Shell #454
metadata.description:
Manual Dutch Auction (DA): 72 · 54 · 40 · 30 · 24 · 20 every 8 minutes.
Auction will stop changing price when non-reserves are fully minted, and then drop one price tier.

---------

The feeling of being human – with all of its intricate hopes, struggles, and fleeting emotions – seems so unique that we assume artificial intelligence could never replicate our experience. And while we devise systems for solving unfathomably complex problems, generating algorithmic creativity, and unlocking regenerative biological possibilities, we simultaneously cling to the power and originality of emotional feeling – believing it to be the irreplaceable source of what makes us human.

If the body is our shell for emotion and soul, can an artificial humanoid be another vessel for these thoughts and feelings – for human essence itself? If our ‘soul’ is the last stand between us and the machines, what happens when the soul becomes transferable? That we may see answers to these questions looks more real every year, and is perhaps a little frightening. 

Emotional Shell uses introspective portraits of future selves to question what it means to be human, when the people around us are no longer human.

---------

Warning: This piece is GPU intensive, it may not render on lower end devices.

Press 1-3 to select from low, medium, and high quality settings
Press 'S' to save the image at the current scale
Press 'H' to save the image at 2400px resolution

Created with Three.js
For third party license information, please see bundle.js.LICENSE.txt

---------

TENDER x wwatkns
August 2022

metadata.name: Возвышение #146
metadata.description:
Возвышение (Eng.: Elevation) is the next step of my study of Suprematism, textures and colours, partially inspired by Lazar Khidekel works. 
The work depicts the superiority of the simplest geometric forms and colours over everything else.

——————

Rendering takes around 20-30 seconds at 60 fps, might take longer on older devices.
Press [Arrow Up / Down] to increase / decrease drawing speed.
Press [1…6] to change an image resolution up to 10k.
Press [S] after the image is rendered to save it.

Created using p5.js.
License: CC BY-NC-SA 4.0.

——————

hrunz. — Sep. 2022.

metadata.name: Provence #399
metadata.description:
The south of France namely the Provence has a cultural history of being an inspiration for impressionists and post-impressionists in the past.
For me personally the Provence is the place i was spending long, peaceful holidays as a child within beautiful nature.
This work does not so much aim for being realistic, rather than give an impression or feeling for this wonderful landscape. 
There are just a few different elements and concepts and yet there is variety of fascinating results.
I really hope you will enjoy your minting.

Notes:
STARTUP AND RENDERING MAY TAKE SOME TIME. (Up to 1min)
Code was written in typescript.
The only used libraries were chroma.js and simplex-noise

metadata.name: Prismatic Thickets #813
metadata.description:
'Prismatic Thickets' is a pure generative painting algorithm; it's not animated nor interactive, but does goes further than any related painting program I've written prior. I created a very large and affordable edition with the hope that collectors can freely explore the emergent potential of the algorithm. 

The Burn (Tuesday, Aug. 23, 2022, 12:05AM UTC):
96 hours after minting opens, all unminted tokens will be burned.

p -> screen capture


Background:
I thought it might be helpful to offer a little background as to why I'm so excited about 'Prismatic Thickets'. 

I began my professional life as a painter; both my degrees are in painting (MFA '92, BFA '89). I got into computing immediately upon completing my MFA. At first, the digital work was to pay the bills (early digital design/illustration/production work.) Soon though, I grew pretty obsessed and started reading computing/software manuals cover-to-cover (yes, dork). At the same time, I was painting, primarily landscapes (plein air).

The plein air painting transitioned from landscapes, to trees, to just branches/leaves, which eventually led to abstract work based primarily on related natural patterns. I also began coding at this time (1994-95). One of my first creative programming projects was based on one of my painted patterned abstractions. I remember the first time I ran my program, saw the coded painting emerge and knew my life would never be the same. This led to an even deeper dive reading programming/math/CS theory textbooks (even bigger dork). 

I quickly realized there were very few programming references for people like me. This eventually led to me writing 3 Processing books and building numerous university creative coding programs around the country. Though this period was exciting, there still remained a major disconnect for me. I hadn't really put my painting background together with my coding background. Obviously, we didn't have marketplaces like fx(hash) back then, to support generative artists. So I essentially took refuge in the ivory tower, creating a gazillion demos, courses, tutorials, workshops, etc.

The worldwide interest in NFT's, especially in the generative space with Art Blocks and fx(hash) has created a venue for creative coders I honestly never thought was possible. It's completely rejuvenated my passion for creative coding and helped me reconnect with some creative coding OG's and many wonderful new artists. So many of the projects I see on Art Blocks and fx(hash) bring me back to the early days and passionate excitement of discovering the generative power of creative coding.

Most of my NFT projects have been fairly dense physics-based experiments. Many of these leverage a codebase I've developed over decades, which I've been slowly porting from Java/P3, C++/OF to TypeScript/three.js. What I hadn't (re)explored was what got me excited about creative coding to begin with: generative painting.


Made with: TypeScript, three.js, PByte.js, Node

In memory of Robert Slutzky

metadata.name: Minima #15
metadata.description:
Minima is a study on focus and color. Playing with the idea of a simple composition of semicircles, either rotated up or down. The focus of the observer is moved with the use of gradual animation in the gradients and occasional circles and/or rectangles connecting the shapes together through color.

The name minima stems from the origins of the composition, mostly taking inspiration from minimalism in its use of a few elements to form a composition greater than the sum of its parts. Less is more, as they say.

The point at the bottom right of the canvas resembles the end of a sentence. Like reading a book, you process the canvas in a similar way, moving from what pops the most to what the least.

As the reader of this canvas I hope you observe what happens to your focus as the colors gradually move across the screen. The animations themselves are looping based on a noised sine wave, which gives them imperfections, imperfections you can observe.

----

Click / Tap on the bar at the bottom of the canvas to open up the GUI, used to export your minima into any format you want. Either .png or .svg. Ready for printing, if you desire.

ps. there might be a secret keyboard shortcut...

----

Minima,
Wouter Missler, 2022,
p5js + webgl.

metadata.name: ____ - Iteration 1 #300
metadata.description:
This project is part of a larger experiment that explores and celebrates the process of making generative art by progressively releasing iterations, working towards a final release on my main account (tz1RkYY3jr1ocuPdQqrRefr5FqoawKQsmBmD). The iterations will be titled ____ 0.1, ____ 0.2, etc. At this point, the number of iterations has not been determined, but more information will be provided as this experiment unfolds.

The final release will only be made available to those who have collected each iteration (using an allowlist), and will be released for free.
